trans-unit.source: Get Started with Event Hubs
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Event Hubs

trans-unit.source: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure Event Hubs; sending events in C and receiving hem in C# using the EventProcessorHost.
trans-unit.target: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure Event Hubs; sending events in C and receiving hem in C# using the EventProcessorHost.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Event Hubs
trans-unit.target: Get started with Event Hubs

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Event Hubs is a highly scalable ingestion system that can intake millions of events per second, enabling an application to process and analyze the massive amounts of data produced by your connected devices and applications.
trans-unit.target: Event Hubs is a highly scalable ingestion system that can intake millions of events per second, enabling an application to process and analyze the massive amounts of data produced by your connected devices and applications.

trans-unit.source: Once collected into Event Hubs, you can transform and store data using any real-time analytics provider or storage cluster.
trans-unit.target: Once collected into Event Hubs, you can transform and store data using any real-time analytics provider or storage cluster.

trans-unit.source: For more information, please see [Event Hubs Overview].
trans-unit.target: For more information, please see [Event Hubs Overview].

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to ingest messages into an Event Hub using a console application in C, and to retrieve them in parallel using the C# [Event Processor Host] library.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to ingest messages into an Event Hub using a console application in C, and to retrieve them in parallel using the C# [Event Processor Host] library.

trans-unit.source: In order to complete this tutorial you will need the following:
trans-unit.target: In order to complete this tutorial you will need the following:

trans-unit.source: A C development environment.
trans-unit.target: A C development environment.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, we will assume the gcc stack on an <link><linkText>Azure Linux VM</linkText><title></title></link> with Ubuntu 14.04.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, we will assume the gcc stack on an <link><linkText>Azure Linux VM</linkText><title></title></link> with Ubuntu 14.04.

trans-unit.source: Instructions for other environments will be provided in external links.
trans-unit.target: Instructions for other environments will be provided in external links.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: <html></html>If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Create an Event Hub
trans-unit.target: Create an Event Hub

trans-unit.source: Log on to the [Azure portal], and click NEW at the bottom of the screen.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the [Azure portal], and click NEW at the bottom of the screen.

trans-unit.source: Click App Services, then Service Bus, then Event Hub, then Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: Click App Services, then Service Bus, then Event Hub, then Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: Type a name for your Event Hub, select your desired region, and then click Create a new Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Type a name for your Event Hub, select your desired region, and then click Create a new Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: Click the namespace you just created (usually *event hub name*-ns).
trans-unit.target: Click the namespace you just created (usually *event hub name*-ns).

trans-unit.source: Click the Event Hubs tab at the top of the page, and then click the Event Hub you just created.
trans-unit.target: Click the Event Hubs tab at the top of the page, and then click the Event Hub you just created.

trans-unit.source: Click the Configure tab at the top of the page, add a rule named SendRule with Send rights, add another rule called ReceiveRule with Manage, Send, Listen rights, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click the Configure tab at the top of the page, add a rule named SendRule with Send rights, add another rule called ReceiveRule with Manage, Send, Listen rights, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: On the same page, take note of the generated keys for SendRule.
trans-unit.target: On the same page, take note of the generated keys for SendRule.

trans-unit.source: Click the Dashboard tab at the top of the page, and then click Connection Information.
trans-unit.target: Click the Dashboard tab at the top of the page, and then click Connection Information.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the two connection strings.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the two connection strings.

trans-unit.source: Your Event Hub is now created, and you have the connection strings you need to send and receive events.
trans-unit.target: Your Event Hub is now created, and you have the connection strings you need to send and receive events.

trans-unit.source: Run the applications
trans-unit.target: Run the applications

trans-unit.source: Now you are ready to run the applications.
trans-unit.target: Now you are ready to run the applications.

trans-unit.source: Run the Receiver project from Visual Studio, then wait for it to start the receivers for all the partitions.
trans-unit.target: Run the Receiver project from Visual Studio, then wait for it to start the receivers for all the partitions.

trans-unit.source: Run the sender program, and see the events appear in the receiver window.
trans-unit.target: Run the sender program, and see the events appear in the receiver window.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: Now that you've built a working application that creates an Event Hub and sends and receives data, you can move on to the following scenarios:

trans-unit.target: A complete [sample application that uses Event Hubs].

trans-unit.target: The [Scale out Event Processing with Event Hubs] sample.

trans-unit.target: A [queued messaging solution] using Service Bus queues.
